messages.title: SIX reasons to re-elect Chris PHILP
messages.content: Chris has successfully campaigned over the last four years including £350m to help fix Brighton Mainline problems, Secured a one third cut in Business Rates for small shops, Secured morning opening hours at Purley Hospital GP Hub, etc.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: Campaigning on local issues, including securing funding for Brighton Mainline problems and business rate cuts for small shops.
Commitment to increase the number of police officers in Croydon.
Opposition to the current administration's planning policies, support for empowering local people over planning decisions.
Advocacy for the opening of new healthcare facilities and support for education.
Support for concluding Brexit to end the uncertainty.
Policies aimed towards achieving a strong economy, including low taxes and support for businesses.

mentions.candidate: Chris Philp has been involved in various local initiatives and successful campaigns.
mentions.otherPartyLeaderCandidate: References to Jeremy Corbyn as the alternative option to Chris Philp.
mentions.tacticalSituation: Comparison of previous election results to illustrate the tactical situation: 'Conservatives 29,874, Labour 21,928, Lib Dems 3,541, UKIP 1,497. Can't win here'

politicalExperience.achievements: Successful campaigns on local issues, securing funding for Brighton Mainline problems, and business rate cuts for small shops.

quotes.text: Chris has been a great support to me and my Chemist's project - Better Health for everyone in the community. He has not stopped!

Thank you for all your help with our Purley project, we're very grateful. We can now look towards further improvements in the High Street. This is some of which we can be proud is happening because we have the go-getter MP!

images.caption: Chris Philp pictured with supporters and constituents.

leaflet.additionalNotes: The leaflet implies the choice between re-electing Chris Philp or having Jeremy Corbyn as an alternative, underlining a Conservative versus Labour dichotomy.
